awd_titl_txt: EAGER Germination Renewal: Cultivating Creativity in STEM Research through Mindfulness Training
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description: A multidisciplinary collaborative team from the University of Wisconsin (UW)-Madison and the University of Virginia (UVa) is pursuing a renewal project to further investigate, refine, and evaluate inter-institutional implementation of a new learning framework recently piloted at UW-Madison for engineering graduate students. The framework is based on mindfulness training, i.e. instruction in meditation and other contemplative practices. The underlying hypothesis is two-fold: 1) mindfulness training will cultivate creativity, innovation, intellectual risk-taking, altruism, and overall well-being, and 2) these characteristics will enhance trainees' ability to conceive of and pursue novel research ideas that address societal challenges. Importantly, because engineering and computer science graduate students frequently transition to research careers in academia, industry and national laboratories where they will become the next generation of innovators in their field, enhancing their creative capacity will benefit society through the innovations they produce both in the short term and over the course of their careers. Mindfulness training also has the potential to benefit the participants' overall health and emotional well-being.

Technical Description: The College of Engineering and the Center for Healthy Minds at the University of Wisconsin (UW)-Madison are partnering with the School of Engineering and Applied Science and the Contemplative Sciences Center at the University of Virginia (UVa) to pursue an expansion of a recently conducted, NSF-funded, pilot study of a new mindfulness-training learning framework for engineering graduate students. The framework is intended to cultivate creativity, innovation, intellectual risk-taking, and altruism -- all of which are at the heart of conceiving and conducting transformative engineering research that focuses on societal grand challenges. The rationale for introducing graduate students to contemplative practices is two-fold. First, recent studies suggest that mindfulness meditation improves insight problem solving, reduces cognitive rigidity, and positively impacts creativity outcomes, as well as increasing empathy and compassion. These links are further supported by underlying theories about the neuroscientific mechanisms of mindfulness. Additionally, mindfulness meditation has been shown to have numerous health benefits, both emotional and physical, including reduced stress, and thus has the potential to holistically increase one's capacity for creativity and societally-focused innovation. The specific objective of this renewal project is to refine the "Cultivating Transformative Research Through Mindfulness" training program based on data from the pilot study, investigate its impact with a larger cohort of graduate students at UW-Madison, and assess transferability of the learning framework to UVa. The project is expected to yield extensive evidence of the efficacy of mindfulness training as an inherently scalable and adaptable learning framework for training engineering and computer science graduate students, enhancing their ability and interest to conduct innovative societally-focused transformative research.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this Germination renewal project was to refine a mindfulness training program previously piloted with engineering graduate students at the University of Wisconsin (UW)-Madison, investigate its impact with a larger cohort of engineering and computer science graduate students at the UW-Madison, and assess the transferability of the training program to the University of Virginia (UVA), another representative research-intensive university. Contemplative neuroscience research studies have demonstrated that brain plasticity can be exploited via mindfulness training to produce measurable effects on brain function and overall well-being. Our hypothesis was that mindfulness training would increase students' creativity as well as empathy, compassion, and overall physical and emotional well-being -- all of which collectively contribute to one's ability to engage in intellectual risk-taking and to develop transformative research concepts that address important societal needs.

 

The training program comprised eight 50-minute weekly sessions of mindfulness training taught by experienced facilitators at the UW-Madison and UVA. The program drew from neuroscience-derived concepts detailed in Davidson and Begley's 2012 book "The Emotional Life of Your Brain" and comprised four components designed to cultivate well-being: 1) an introduction to and exploration of the six dimensions of emotional style -- attention, self-awareness, resilience, positive outlook, sensitivity to context, and social intuition -- the combination of which characterize an individual's specific overall emotional style; 2) an overview of the neuroplasticity of the brain and how the brain can be trained to change responses to emotions; 3) training in mindfulness meditation and other contemplative practices, as well as cognitive skills and techniques; and 4) strategies for creating and maintaining healthy mental and emotional habits.

 

The human subject participation was approved and overseen by the Education and Social/Behavioral Science Institutional Review Board at the UW-Madison.  The 211 individuals enrolled in the studies were randomly assigned to intervention and wait-listed control groups at the two universities. Participants in the intervention group completed the mindfulness training immediately (during Fall semester) while participants in the control group completed it later (during Spring semester). Participants in both the intervention and control groups were given pre- and post-test surveys at the same time of the year (at the beginning and the end of the Fall semester), so that any difference observed between the two groups could be attributed to the effect of the mindfulness training and not differences in season or academic stressors that vary throughout the year. The pre- and post-test questionnaires made use of a variety of standard and custom measures designed to assess emotional and physical well-being, creativity, research satisfaction, and desire to contribute to the betterment of society. Participants also completed a summative assessment survey to evaluate the impact and value of the training on their research and well-being. 

 

Intellectual merit:  The intervention groups reported significantly improved emotional well-being at the end of the training. In contrast, the control groups consistently held steady or dropped on their well-being between pre- and post-tests without the training intervention in the middle of the semester.  Specific improvements in the intervention groups, compared to the control groups, included improved emotional health, decreased neuroticism, increased positive affect, decreased negative affect, and increased mindfulness. Intervention groups reported statistically significant improvement in their satisfaction with their research.  We also observed a significant Time by Group interaction for the Creativity Characteristics Scale. According to paired t-tests conducted post-hoc, the intervention group increased in their endorsement of creativity characteristics, while no such effect was observed in the control group.  These findings suggest that mindfulness training has the potential to play a vital professional and personal development role in graduate engineering education.

 

Broader impact: The open-ended responses collected in the summative assessments revealed the impact of the intervention to help students regulate emotion and anger, decrease anxiety, and reduce stress. Of particular importance to the ability to conduct engineering research, the graduate student respondents cited increases in focus and efficiency, improved relations with research colleagues, and enhanced ability to handle research setbacks constructively. A substantial number of participants reported that they continued to practice mindfulness 18-24 months after the program ended, although the average time spend per week did diminish.  Although we were not able to make definitive links to creativity and innovation, the research was successful in demonstrating improved emotional health and overall wellbeing. The eight-week mindfulness-based training program provided to engineering graduate student participants was well-received, produced significant impacts across a number of measures, and was seen by the students as playing an important professional and personal development role in graduate engineering education.  The results were consistent both across cohorts and institutions, thus establishing the feasibility for widespread implementation.
